html:
• anchor

    Photo: Virgile Simon Bertrand

    Zaha Hadid Architects has shared news and photography of their completed Shenzhen Science & Technology Museum. 

    The mammoth centerpiece for the new Guangming Science City equals close to 1.35 million square feet and is part of the firm's expanded focus in the Shenzhen metro region. 

    It joins OPPO Shenzhen headquarters and the Shenzhen Institute of Financial Technology campus, which will be finished later in the year and followed by their winning Shenzhen Bay Super Headquarters Base Tower C competition design in 2027.

    According to the firm's original project announcement: "The design is a volumetric response to the distinct conditions of the site. Responding to the city to the east, the design is defined by its solidity and dynamic curvilinear geometries that express the many urban circulation routes."

    This is notable as the first architectural design to incorporate dual-color INCO technology in a facade system in China. It generates a nanoscopic film layer to sheath the surface of individual stainless steel panels, cleaning the material while providing the added benefit of colorization sans the use of paint. That helps extend the lifecycle of the facade system and building in the process. 

    Undulating blue-gray tones provided by the LEDs will add texture and evoke the museum's purpose as a learning repository in the likeness of swirling celestial bodies. Terraces are embedded in the volume, extending the gallery activities inside and providing public space for the city. Almost half (58,000 square feet) of the program has been dedicated as space for science research activities. 

    The project's procurements, full life-cycle performance, and adaptability for future reconfigurations had been previously evaluated in order to reduce embodied carbon and achieve a Three-Star Green Building Evaluation Standard at the end of construction. 

    Other sustainable outcomes to highlight for the project are the nearly 400,000 tonnes of recycled materials used in construction. 

    MAD Architects will follow ZHA's museum contribution to Guangming Science City with their design for the Shenzhen Bay Culture Park this September.
